[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

COMPETITIVE SALARIES FOR COMPETENT AND HONEST GOVERNMENT
(Motion)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [31st October, 1994],

    "That this House endorses Paper Cmd. 13 of 1994 on "Competitive Salaries for Competent and Honest Government" as the basis for setting salaries of Ministers and senior public officers." - [Prime Minister]

    Question again proposed.

     Mr S. Dhanabalan (Toa Payoh GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, on a point of clarification. I said in my intervention on Tuesday that the general election is the right forum to determine the electorate's support because it puts the issue in a total and correct context. I want to clarify that the point that I wanted to make is that issues like these are not issues that should be decided in isolation through a referendum. These are issues that can be seen in context in a general election. But this does not mean that the motion before this House should be kept in abeyance until the next general election.

Column: 832



    This system of linking Ministers' salaries to private sector salaries was an issue in the last general election. Fine-tuning the system, as is proposed in the White Paper, will, I am sure, be an issue of the next general election and in many more general elections to come until it becomes accepted as conventional wisdom. It does not therefore mean that the motion before the House should be postponed.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Mr Speaker, Sir, after the Senior Minister's speech on Tuesday, putting his prestige and life-long experience behind the concept of benchmarking Ministers' pay to the top income earners in Singapore, there is very little anyone can add to the debate. So I beg your indulgence to let me proceed.

    The concept of benchmarking civil servants and Ministers' compensation with the private sector is, I believe, readily acceptable by most Singaporeans. The question is: where to set the benchmark? In the case of the Ministers, as the Senior Minister has said, who else has the range of experience to judge? Definitely not the general public. I do not know about my colleagues in this House, but I would definitely disqualify myself to judge as well. Perhaps the persons to judge, besides himself, would include the Prime Minister, the serving Ministers and those retired Ministers.

    Since it would be inappropriate for serving Ministers to comment on their own compensation, this House could benefit from the input of our immediate past Ministers, namely, Mr Dhanabalan, Dr Tony Tan and Dr Yeo Ning Hong. Mr Dhanabalan has spoken. I have always respected Mr Dhanabalan. From the many discussions we had with him in the Members' Room, one can come to the conclusion that he is a righteous man, a religious man, a man of high moral principles. On Tuesday, when he disclosed that he did not even know how much he would be paid when he first entered politics, I applauded. My esteem for him has climbed up several notches. Mr Dhanabalan said that he is old-fashioned and belongs to the age of

Column: 833

dinosaurs. He conceded that the new benchmark for Ministers will give the Prime Minister the tools to assemble his team. I believe we should listen to him very carefully.

    On the other hand, how about Dr Tony Tan and Dr Yeo Ning Hong? What do they have to say about the new benchmark? I would be glad to listen to them.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would agree that if pay, and pay alone, is the way of getting successful Singaporeans into the Cabinet, we should remove that stumbling block once and for all. In fact, why stop at two-thirds? I say, pay the man his market rate or more to attract him into the Cabinet.

    On the other hand, without sounding disrespectful, may I ask the Senior Minister and the Prime Minister whether pay alone will solve the problem. This problem is not new. The Senior Minister himself admitted that he had been grappling with it for a long time. And yet, he always mentions increasing the Ministers' pay from time to time to tackle this problem. As such, I have gained the impression that the Cabinet seems to think this problem is purely one-dimensional.

    With my limited experience as a manager, what I have learned working for a multinational company like IBM and Xerox, recruiting and keeping the right people in the company, my understanding is that human resource management is a multi-faceted issue. These corporations' research shows that time and again, pay in itself is ultimately not a motivating factor. Pay increase that is tied to performance is a motivating factor, but absolute pay level itself is not. One does not throw money at the problem just to solve it, unless one is looking for a quick fix. Maybe more senior and more experienced managers in this House, including CEOs, will bear me out in this issue.

    Sir, I am not sure whether anyone has taken note of the various factors people

Column: 834

have mentioned when they declined invitations to join the Cabinet. As Mr Dhanabalan said, those who declined rarely mentioned pay. Did they mention others and did the Cabinet look into those other negative factors? Have we tried to do something about those factors? Dr Ow chin Hock, in his speech, mentioned a few factors, such as relationship between fellow members in the Cabinet, teamwork, job satisfaction, and I would add another to this list, career path. I believe anyone of ministerial calibre in Singapore will definitely ask what is the career path for him if he were to join the Cabinet. What is life after being a Minister? Is joining the Cabinet a right career choice? Would a stint in Cabinet give his career a boost or is it, like the Senior Minister said, walking into the sunset after leaving the Cabinet? I think all he or she has to do is to take a look at the retired Ministers and he will come to the conclusion that the prospect is not that promising.

    The Senior Minister mentioned in his speech that a former Cabinet Minister has petitioned to the Prime Minister for an adjustment in his pension. We all know that Dr Goh Keng Swee left GIC and became a paid consultant. Even our immediate past Ministers, Dr Yeo Ning Hong and Mr Dhanabalan, still physically very healthy and strong, and very agile mentally, have already retired. The impression one gets is that for these very good men, the best years were taken out of their life and, once out of the Cabinet, they are left on their own. Is this impression not a major deterrent for anyone intending to join the Cabinet? So I would like to ask: can pay alone overcome this problem?

    The answer is yes, but to do so, just as the Senior Minister has recommended, the level has to be set very high, tying to the top income earners in this land. But would it not be better if a stint as a Minister is considered a step upward so that career-minded Singaporeans will find it attractive to serve? Would it also be kinder to the men and women who had served the nation well?

Column: 835



    When I speak up, do I begrudge the Ministers for their pay? Absolutely not. As an old Member of Parliament, who has since retired, used to say, "Ministers are paid not just for what they do, but are also paid for what they can't do, don't do, and will not do.' Very simple words. Very wise words. 'Can't do, don't do, and will not do' but they succinctly capture the gist of the matter. I say our Ministers deserve every dollar they make.

    Why then am I taking the time of this House to delve into a topic so forcefully and eloquently dealt with by none other than the Senior Minister? Because of the various immediate ramifications. Let us stop for a minute and think one step beyond the immediate problem of getting talented and targeted people into the Cabinet. What are Cabinet Ministers? They are also political leaders. They have to win elections. Mr Dhanabalan said that they have to bring the Party through the next general election and future general elections. So let us stop and think about the problems these Ministers would face in mobilising the people when everyone in Singapore knows that when they look at the Ministers they are one of the top 100 earners in Singapore, come high or lo.

    As political leaders, besides GDP growth, price of our homes, employment, our Ministers have to sell unpopular policies to the people. To name a few, reduced medical benefits to civil servants, higher COEs, GST and, at times of crisis, we have to ask our people to make sacrifices. Just think about how the people would have reacted if this pay formula were in place when the Deputy Prime Minister, then Minister for Trade and Industry, moved in this House to cut CPF contribution of everyone in Singapore by 15% to pull the nation out of the 1985 recession. A big question mark, isn't it?

    Sir, political leaders are also entrusted with making very difficult and tough decisions that will touch our lives very deeply. Past decisions of this nature include calling up young men for national service, mother tongue education, restriction of right to reside in

Column: 836

Singapore for foreign spouse, corrective work orders, etc. Future decisions could involve sending our young men into combat in defence of Singapore. Only political leaders with the moral authority to lead could make such decisions and be obeyed. I think we should not dilute that moral authority. Hence, the calibre of a political leader cannot be measured by his earning power alone inside or outside the Government. Neither should we select one just because he is very successful in his own profession.

    As political leaders, our Ministers have to mobilise grassroots leaders in the RCs, MCs and the CCCs, all of whom are volunteers. The Senior Minister spoke about them and how they are the people that turn the concrete jungle of Singapore into a living community. These people serve without pay and often times dig into their pockets to pay in order to serve the community. I think this emphasis on Ministers' pay would not go down very well with them. Even before a single new blood could be inducted into the Cabinet under the new formula, every serving Minister's pay would have gone up. I believe the prestige of the Ministers might be eroded in the short term since they will be the main beneficiaries under this proposal. This disruption in rapport would take time to amend. Thus, I find the timing of this White Paper to be a bit perplexing. With the next general election rumoured to be just around the corner, Mr Speaker, Sir, why do we choose this time to introduce a very, very touchy subject?

    Sir, this problem of paying our political leaders well and yet at the same time have to placate voters' sentiments is not unique. In fact, it is an inherent problem of the parliamentary system we inherited from the British. The Prime Minister in his speech already pointed out the corruption in the current British Parliament arises partly because of this reason - poor pay. The Senior Minister also pointed out in his speech that the calibre of the British Minister is not high compared to the private sector, for the very same reason. So is it possible to say that the system itself is part of the problem? If we were to have high pay

Column: 837

for our Ministers, who is to say that no future Singaporean politician will use the slogan, "Vote for me, and I'll cut the Minister's pay by half," and thereby win votes and get into Parliament.

    I remember, as a young man, when the Senior Minister, who was then the Prime Minister, cut his own pay and all the pay of the civil servants, I applauded. Today, wouldn't a young man applaud another politician vowing to do the same thing, and gaining a lot of popular support?

    Sir, the United States, which was also a British colony, did not adopt the Westminster system when it became independent slightly over 200 years ago. Why? Perhaps their founding fathers did not change the system just to be different. Perhaps they had given this problem of recruiting talent into government some very deep thought. Because, at that time in their history, theirs was a new country without a landed ruling class, like the British. It was a situation very similar to Singapore. They innovated and devised a new system with separation of the judiciary, legislature and the executive. A member of the US executive can be inducted straight from the private sector. The best could be nominated by the President and confirmed by the legislature. To distinguish them from the politicians, they are even given a different title - Secretary of Department. They serve their terms, they contribute to the nation and they return to the private sector.

    The Senior Minister says that political entrepreneurs are needed for success. That is true. And he looks for them in the private sector. But this process of selecting and inducting capable and talented individuals from the private sector is not part of the Westminster model of government that we have in Singapore. It is more like the US executive mode of government. May I humbly suggest that this is also part of the root cause of the difficulty in inducting talent into the Cabinet. We are trying to use a very old instrument, the

Column: 838

British Cabinet system, to serve the needs of the Government in a very modern world. The White Paper proposes a mechanism using pay to overcome this problem of the system. May I ask the Prime Minister whether we should look into introducing fundamental changes in the Cabinet system to address this? Perhaps we too should innovate and create a new system to meet Singapore's needs. Could we not have a mixture of political and non-political Ministerial positions in the Cabinet? Could we not use the NMP mechanism to induct private sector talent at their existing income, existing pay, into those non-political posts? These are not new ideas. The Deputy Prime Minister, in moving the NMP Bill, had touched on this.

    When the Cabinet has serving Members from the private sector, drawing private sector pay, then benchmarking political Ministers' pay would no longer be a matter of faith. I believe there are merits in this proposal, the details of which can be delved into later. Basically, I think it would be a shame that at this time, when the House is debating a substantive change to the Ministers' pay package, we do not explore this option as well.

    Sir, I think we have to decide whether our Ministers are political leaders or just very capable political entrepreneurs. As long as we prefer our Ministers to be political leaders, our people would like to see them as individuals, motivated by idealism, fired by a sense of mission and driven by a desire to serve.

     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe (Marine Parade GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, like Dr Wang, it is really difficult to make a contribution after the Senior Minister has spoken. In fact, I had to revise my speech after Monday. And after the Senior Minister has spoken, I really do not know how to revise my speech. Anyway, Sir, with your indulgence, I would like to make a contribution and a few comments on the proposed White Paper.

    Sir, the business of government is becoming more complex and we have to

Column: 839

ensure that we can get a fair share of our top talents from the public as well as the private sectors to take the challenge of political leadership, to become a Minister or to serve in other political appointments. Good government should not be taken for granted. The issue today is how we should attract top talents into Government and how they should be compensated to ensure that they will not be lured away by the attraction of the private sector in Singapore as well as the booming regional economies.

    Sir, on the salaries of Ministers, I would like to make the following suggestions. I would like to suggest the establishment of an independent salary commission for Ministers and political appointments compensation package. This is not a new proposal. Some Members of this House have raised it before. It will not solve the problem, but I believe it will help to minimise or moderate it.

    Sir, one of the criticisms of the White Paper is that the Ministers are setting their own salaries. I do not think this is true. It is a wrong perception. Let us therefore remove this unnecessary difficulty so that the issue of what is a right compensation package for Ministers and political appointments can be examined in a fair and objective way.

    The key task of the commission is to ensure that there is a proper compensation package so that we will be able to attract a fair share of good and honest men and women into Government. The commission can examine the salary and compensation package of the private sector, the sacrifices made by those who join Government, including the loss of opportunities, especially for those who resign from the private sector in their early 30s or 40s to enter politics.

    How we pay or compensate the Ministers and other political appointments today is different from how Ministers were paid in the past. And it may well be different in the way Ministers and others in politics will be paid in the future. The motivational factor will be different. They will change with time and with each succeeding generation.

Column: 840



    Sir, just let me give an example which appeared in yesterday's Straits Times. I believe Members must have read yesterday's Straits Times, at page 3, the report entitled "UK Minister also a part-time dentist". The report said that one of the British Government's newest Ministers had been given permission by the British Prime Minister to work three days a week as a private dentist. I am not sure whether we need to go into such an arrangement in the future. But if we have to do so, then it would be better if such a recommendation comes from an independent commission, made up of successful businessmen, private sector managers and professionals. We may well have to do so if we take in persons who only want to serve a short term in Government. Here, perhaps let me just quote what the Minister, Sir Paul Beresford said:

    `I don't expect to remain in politics all my life so I need to keep my hand in as a dentist.'

It may well be that some of these leaders that we want to attract may just want to serve a short term in Government and want to keep abreast of changes in whatever professions they come from, and therefore giving them an arrangement like this may well serve a purpose. I am saying that these are some of the things we need to look into and see how it can work, so that we can get the best talents in Government.

    Sir, on the proposal to work out a benchmark, I agree with proposals made by some Members that instead of working on the average earnings of the top four earners in the six professions, which some have pointed out to be individual or person-based, we should work instead on a percentile basis, taking the top 10-15 percentile for Ministers. Here, we will broaden the base. Taking this approach, I do not think we need to work on a discount basis, but just pay the Ministers based on the average of what the top 10-15 percentile are paid.

    As a trade union leader, it is not easy for me to explain to workers the proposal to pay Ministers salaries which are mind-boggling, especially when their average salary is around $1,000-$1,500 per month. However, we have to accept

Column: 841

the reality. We have to be realistic. If we want good government, we want to be competitive, we want to have sustainable economic growth, we want good jobs and a good quality of life, then we must have good talents in Government and we must compensate them well.

    Sir, on the civil service, I agree that we should pay competitive salaries to attract some of the best to serve in the civil service. Here, we are focusing on the top end, that is salaries for the Administrative Service officers. I think we should also look at the salaries of the other levels, right to the junior levels and pay them salaries which are competitive and in accordance with their performance and contribution. To have an effective civil service, the civil service must work as a team. We cannot have feelings that some are paid much better or more than what they deserve while others are not given the right salaries. I hope that with this system of Personnel Boards which is now being introduced in the civil service, the Personnel Boards will look at the system of compensating civil servants and will make sure that the salaries which the other grades in the civil service are receiving are fair and competitive.

    Sir, on that note, I support the motion.

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam (Sembawang GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in this debate.

    I had not intended to speak in this debate originally, because I had spoken last year, when the subject of Ministers' salaries was discussed, and I thought I made my views clear. So I felt there was no need to repeat myself.

    However, since Dr Wang Kai Yuen has asked for my views, let me just say that whatever I said when this topic was debated at the end of last year, I am still of the same view. In fact, I am even more convinced that you cannot go back to the past. We are dealing with a new generation today. The Government is trying to tackle a very difficult problem, as my colleague, Mr Dhanabalan, said

Column: 842

yesterday. The problem can be stated very simply. As the Senior Minister said, how do you ensure that there will be a continuing inflow of talent, of young people, into the Government to fill the ministerial ranks and the various offices in Government so that Singapore can go ahead. That is the crux of the whole issue.

    The first generation leaders were motivated by the desire to build Singapore. That was the great challenge. For myself and my colleagues, when we were asked to take up office, the challenge that was put to me by the late Finance Minister, Mr Hon Sui Sen, was how to ensure that Singapore could go ahead, that the success of Singapore will not crumble and will not vanish with the passing of the first generation. That was a great challenge. That was something that could motivate people to go into Government then, to give up their private sector jobs.

    I can say, quite honestly, as with my colleague, Mr Dhanabalan, that when you are faced with a challenge like that, salary is not a consideration. But what do we have now? We have a successful Singapore. What are the great challenges? We fine-tune the system. We try and solve the COEs by building more MRT, providing better transport, tinkering with the system. We are also dealing with a younger generation of Singaporeans who are more careful, whose options are wider, who consider more carefully before they decide to take the plunge into politics.

    Sir, these are the realities of life. You cannot change them. I think that it is best for the House to take the bull by the horns. Have a system of remuneration which would pay Ministers and political office-holders well, so that at least you mitigate that difficulty, make it less unattractive for younger people to go into politics and take up office in Government. If you do not do that, in the long run Singapore will be the loser.

    I support the motion to pay competitive salaries for honest and competent Government. I say, support the Prime Minister, give him the tools.

Column: 843

He has a very difficult job. We should not make it more difficult for him. I hope that answers Dr Wang's question.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for giving me the opportunity to speak.

    Singaporeans can say with pride and certainty that we have had an honest and competent Government since the PAP came into power. Singaporeans can also say with certainty that we want to continue to attract people who will form an honest and competent Government. But how do we achieve this? That is the burning question. That is what we should be debating and not the formula or the benchmark or the various permutations and computations of it. But how do we get honest and competent people into Government?

    The problem that the Prime Minister faces and that all of us face in this country is how do we ensure that we will continue to have political leaders who are competent and honest people with vision, and the bureaucracy remains clean and effective. Although this is a national challenge, it is the Prime Minister who bears the most immediate and direct responsibility, and we all have to help him in his task, as Dr Tony Tan just said.

    However, this challenge is very complex and there is no single obvious solution. But it appears to me and many other Singaporeans that the White Paper seems to suggest that the answer lies in increasing the remuneration, and once this is done, the problem will be solved. I think this financial approach to a problem of human motivation is a unifaceted answer and even a little simplistic. I think my colleague, Dr Wang Kai Yuen, also talked about this.

    The Prime Minister in his speech said that he wants the most capable and most honest people in his team, and to ensure this, he has taken the pragmatic approach of offering higher financial rewards to Ministers and top civil servants. The Prime Minister has made an appeal to give him our backing.

Column: 844



    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Prime Minister knows that many of us in Singapore would go a long way to give him our support. There is no question about that. But many of us feel, and I am reflecting what other Singaporeans have told me, that we would be neglecting our duty if we did not point out to the Prime Minister that we do not agree with him that the White Paper offers the solution that he is looking for. He has said that the formula dealt in the White Paper would head off the problem of weak leadership in future years. Sir, with due respect to the Prime Minister, the answer is not so simple and it may not be the answer at all.

    Let us ask ourselves a few fundamental questions: Why are able Singaporeans reluctant to take on the risks and public responsibilities of a political career? Is pay the main motivator? If we increase the remuneration even more from the present reasonably high level, will we be able to attract the right talent? By increasing the salaries of Ministers to what might seem astronomical levels to the person in the street, are we risking a possible political backlash? Let us go to the first important question: Why are able Singaporeans reluctant to take on the risk and public responsibilities of a political career? The White Paper proposes a solution to this problem, but let us look at the problem first. Before we can appoint Ministers, we have to look for MPs. Only after becoming MPs and showing their mettle and ability, can we follow up by appointing them Ministers.

    On 23rd March 1989, Mr Lee Kuan Yew, then Prime Minister of Singapore, said in this House, and I quote [Hansard, Vol. 53, Col. 805]:

    `To get good Ministers, you must have good MPs because they come from the MPs."

    The crux of the matter, therefore, Mr Speaker, as implied by our former Prime Minister, is not that we cannot find enough good people to become Ministers, but that we cannot find enough good people to become MPs. Therefore, what we should be doing is

Column: 845

not reviewing the salaries of Ministers, but trying to get at the reasons why people are not keen to come forward to become MPs and Ministers. Could one reason be the great affective divide written about so eloquently by Catherine Lim, one of our foremost writers? Should we be looking into this lack of bonding between the present leaders and the people, especially those with the potential but not the willingness to come forward for political office? Could another reason be that we have depoliticised our citizenry? Could yet another reason be that we do not have a responsive national framework to allow people to participate in the political arena? Whatever the reasons, Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sure that remuneration has little to do with the reluctance to come forward into the political sphere.

    To illustrate my point, I would like to quote from a parliamentary speech on 23rd March 1989, made by Mr Goh Chok Tong, then First Deputy Prime Minister, when he talked about the difficulties of recruiting political talent and giving examples of reluctant politicians [Hansard, Vol. 53, Col. 751]:

    `Do you know how many times I had to see Dr Richard Hu, Wong Kan Seng, George Yeo, Mah Bow Tan and Seet Ai Mee before they said "yes"? At least three times each and over many months.'

Mr Goh Chok Tong then went on to say [Hansard, Vol. 53, Col. 752]:

    `I got them to say "yes" - Dr Richard Hu, Wong Kan Seng, and the others because I persisted and appealed to their sense of duty, duty to their fellow citizens, to their friends and relatives and to their own family. Even if we had paid them more than what they were earning, they would still not have come in without intense persuasion.'

    Here, Mr Goh Chok Tong has stated very clearly that remuneration did not at all come into consideration when Dr Richard Hu, Mr Wong Kan Seng, BG Yeo, Mr Mah Bow Tan and Dr Seet Ai Mee decided to enter the political arena. They only agreed to step forward as Mr Goh Chok Tong appealed to their sense of service to the nation. Mr Speaker, Sir, does this not teach us a clear lesson? It

Column: 846

is obvious that what persuades worthy people is not a big financial carrot dangling before them, but their sense of duty. Let us not under-estimate the dynamics of the desire to serve the nation and send a wrong signal to the public.

    Next, we come to the question of retaining Ministers. How many of them have left their post because of remuneration? Not Dr Tony Tan, not Mr Dhanabalan, or Dr Yeo Ning Hong, to name a few. Thus, remuneration is definitely not a factor in retaining Ministers. Therefore, although we may never have another Mr Lee Kuan Yew, Dr Goh Keng Swee, Mr Rajaratnam, or Mr Lim Kim San - all of whom entered politics with no thought at all of financial rewards - Singapore has not done so badly after all. We still have the likes of Dr Richard Hu, Mr Wong Kan Seng, BG Yeo, Mr Mah Bow Tan, Dr Seet Ai Mee, Dr Ker Sin Tze and Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee. None of these people were motivated by money. Now we have heard Mr Dhanabalan and Dr Tony Tan bear testimony to the same fact. I am sure this applies to all our present leaders.

    In the face of this overwhelming proof of the altruism of our present batch of leaders, how can we say that altruism died with the days of Mr Lee Kuan Yew and the Old Guards? However, if we persist in equating public service so closely and intimately with high remuneration, then we will surely kill altruism and infect our younger generation with the seeds of non-altruism. Are we inadvertently breeding materialism in our able young people and making light of their nobler instinct? Let us all look at our own children. Do they appear to us to value only money? If the answer is yes, then have we abdicated our duty and our role to instil the right values of idealism and service to the nation into our children? What have we been doing? It may be time, then, to look at ourselves and not just accept that conditions have changed and the younger generation looks only for material rewards, and then cater for this base instinct by jacking up the salaries.

Column: 847



    In spite of what some other people may think, I have faith in the younger generation. They are no better or worse off than us. After all, we made them. I disagree that there are no challenges left for Singapore leaders. I think the greatest challenge we face is the management of our success, and this will not continue if we just fine-tune our policies. In fact, the challenge is even greater now. Creating wealth is one big challenge but to manage success is yet a greater challenge.

    Now, Mr Speaker, Sir, let us go back to the financial sacrifice written about in the White Paper. We are given to understand that many of the best in our land who are in the private sector will not come into politics because of the financial sacrifice they have to make, and their families will not accept this. This thesis is not valid. Because we already have in place a mechanism to reward those able people who are willing to leave the private sector and take on the public responsibility of becoming a Minister or a Minister of State. The mechanism of make-up pay for Ministers ensures that there is no financial sacrifice. This important provision has not been mentioned at all in this debate. The existence of this provision removes an important pillar for the rationale of increasing remuneration for Ministers.

    Let me first elaborate on the provision of make-up pay. Here I would like to quote again what Mr Goh Chok Tong who, as the First Deputy Prime Minister, said in this House on 23rd March 1989, and I quote [Hansard, Vol. 53, Col. 758]:

    `Even with the higher salary grades for Ministers, we will still want from time to time to induct successful and able men from the private sector into the Cabinet, men who are earning far more than the revised pay for Ministers, to serve for one or perhaps two terms. If such a person has first to be tried out for a period as a Minister of State before being appointed a full Minister, the problem becomes more acute.

    To accommodate these possibilities without upsetting the protocol order, the Government is introducing a system of make-up pay, similar to that practised with reservist national servicemen.

    In future when a Minister or a Minister of State is appointed, he may receive make-up pay in addition to his rank pay. In other words, if he earns more than that of a Minister of State and he is

Column: 848

appointed as a Minister of State, the difference will be paid to him by way of a make-up pay, but he will not receive the entire difference. He will receive only up to 90% of that difference. The calculation will be based on his income tax returns for the last two years before his appointment. The make-up pay will not be carried on for ever. A Minister can continue to receive this for up to two terms of office.'

    Mr Goh then continued:

    `We are introducing this system of make-up pay because I believe this will enable the country to benefit from the services of those who do not wish to make politics their entire career, but who have a contribution to make to the nation. They can now become Ministers without having to make too much of a sacrifice.'

I would like to repeat the last sentence of what Mr Goh said: "They can now become Ministers without having to make too much of a sacrifice." Well, that says it all. With this system of make-up pay in operation, what is the rationale for the new benchmark to attract top private sector talent into political office?

    Mr Goh Chok Tong then went on to say -

    `The system of make-up pay will not apply to existing office-holders. It will be used primarily to induct successful people between 35 and 45 years of age to be tried out as Ministers of State before they are appointed as Ministers.'

I presume that the make-up pay provision is still valid as I could find no later statement rescinding or abolishing it.

    Aside from the provision of make-up pay, a Minister who has served eight years is entitled to a pension and he can return to the private sector. Public sector service significantly appreciates the value of the individual concerned, by virtue of its function and demands, and the private sector recognises this. What I am saying, Mr Speaker, is that an ex-minister has enhanced value.

    From what has been said in this House, I understand that both Dr Ker Sin Tze and Prof. Ho Peng Kee did not apply for make-up pay even though they were earning more in the private sector. What does this say? Money is not what motivates people.

    Now, I would like to address the other less tangible elements of sacrifice - the loss of privacy, the loss of family time,

Column: 849

etc. This is the price paid by anyone who is prominent in public or community service and is thus unavoidable. Money cannot compensate for this personal sacrifice.

    But the other side of this sacrifice for Ministers is the challenge of being able to help forge a dynamic society, of being able to put their beliefs into practice and being able to have the freedom to live by their ethical values.

    Many of us would consider exercising these privileges the highest reward and we would give an arm and a leg to be able to realise these ideals and beliefs. This is the other face of the sacrifice that Ministers have to make. In fact, this may be the most important perk and not a sacrifice at all.

    Mr Speaker, if we keep on insisting that money is a major factor in attracting and retaining our Ministers, then some grave consequences could follow. Our citizenry could become disillusioned with the output of our Ministers. There will be an erosion of leading by social ideals. What about our national ideology of putting society above self? Our young people will be seduced by the belief that a man's worth can only be measured in gold. Surely, this is not a part of our Asian and Confucian values or of our national ideology of shared values.

    Furthermore, if we pay our Ministers salaries comparable to the top earners in the private sector, will this cause public cynicism and lead to the view that a Minister is just another paid knowledge-worker? Here, I would like to quote the Straits Times editorial of 25th October 1994:

    `Put bluntly, it is clearer than ever before that a Minister is, in many ways, no different from other wage earners.'

Is this the public attitude we want to foster towards those holding high political office? Do we want the loss of prestige for our leaders, as has happened in many other countries? Prime Minister Goh once said that the political leaders of Singapore are its "Jun Zi" (wise and

Column: 850

benevolent leaders and not enticed by profit). If we tarnish this image, then will this not also affect the mandate of the political leaders to rule with wisdom and benevolence? We cannot afford a possible public backlash of cynicism and disillusionment against our present leaders. This could lead to a freak election result - a result that the PAP and many of us in Singapore dread most and want least.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would therefore like to urge the Prime Minister to exercise caution and restraint in increasing the salaries of the Ministers further. Reasonable Singaporeans, and there are plenty of us around, accept that our Ministers must be paid well. We respect and look up to our Ministers and to the Prime Minister and realise the tremendous responsibility on their shoulders. We, therefore, do not grudge them at all their present salaries which have been revised substantially since January 1994. However, if we keep on talking about the worth of Ministers in monetary terms, then the attitude of our people will harden and they will question, query and probe the inter-relationship between political office, public service and remuneration and weigh the worth of each on a weighing scale.

    I, therefore, earnestly urge the Prime Minister to leave things as they are where the salary of Ministers is concerned.

    We have already seen that pay has not been the motivating factor in getting our present batch of leaders. Pay has also not been responsible for them leaving office. Also, with the make-up pay scheme in place, we are not being prevented in recruiting people from the private sector because of monetary concerns.

    So, Mr Speaker, why do we want to raise the pay of Ministers further? It, therefore, appears to me that the White Paper is suggesting a solution to our problem which does not exist. The problem is not the lack of financial rewards that prevent people from

Column: 851

accepting the offer of political office. The problem is that people do not want to take on the challenge of political office. Money has little or nothing to do with it.

    As Prof. Walter Woon put it well earlier, it makes little difference to the quality of one's life or the life of one's family when you look at salaries beyond $60,000 per month. Beyond this reasonable and comfortable level, a further rise is like superfluous icing on a healthy cake. The icing does not make much difference to the baking of the cake but adds an unhealthy quality to the end product and here, the icing on the cake could extract a political cost.

    Now, Mr Speaker, let me turn to the top civil servants' salary. According to the World Bank Report of 1992 which is shown in the Annex of the White Paper, Singapore pays its bureaucrats the best in the region. According to the table produced by the World Bank, public sector salaries exceed private sector salaries in Singapore. The comparison used is the upper quartile and this standard seems to be the accepted standard by the World Bank and internationally. Many private sector organisations also pay their top people salaries in the upper quartile as compared to others in the industry.

    The present Superscale G annual income is $150,000 after the 1st January revision and this is what a bright 32 year old gets now as an Administrative Officer. The salary of $150,000 per year is 75% of the benchmark suggested by the White Paper. I realise there is a two year lag between the private and public sectors in using the suggested benchmark. However, we are not taking into account the civil service pension which adds another 15%. We are also not taking into account the prestige, job security and other advantages of public employment. Here, I would like to quote from the editorial of Lianhe Zaobao of 24th October 1994, as reported in the Business Times:

    `... profit constitutes the most important factor in the private sector. When a company makes a lot of money, its senior staff members benefit from it. However, in bad times, it is not uncommon for them to suffer a pay cut or even retrenchment. On the

Column: 852

other hand, civil servants, including those in very senior positions, need not face such risks. So it is important to ensure that the basic principles of public service are not violated when salaries of the public and private sectors are linked.'

    I think many Members of this House have voiced their doubts on how inappropriate the 15P32 benchmark is. However, we also need to question whether the basic premise underlying the benchmark is valid, that is, the way to attract and retain top civil servants is by giving them competitive wages with the private sector. Is this premise true?

    Derek Bok retired as the President of Harvard University in 1991 and spent a year writing a book on what should determine "The Cost of Talent" which is the title of his study. "Economists", argues Mr Bok, "will respond that if we do not let the market decide matters of compensation, who will? Yet even if no better alternative comes to mind, thoughtful people will look upon the results, not with comprehension and respect, but with bewildered disbelief." He was referring to the payroll of football teams, but this could equally apply to the benchmarks being proposed for top civil servants and Ministers. He goes on to say that factors other than money obviously influence career choices:

    `The interest of the work involved - its intellectual challenge, the opportunities to be creative and exercise initiative ... the kinds of people who will be your colleagues ... the chance to help others.'

    Mr Speaker, Sir, income is not the sum total of human life. This holds true even for the bright young people, whom we are so eager to label as caring only for material rewards. In the light of this analytical thinking, should we not review the whole picture of why bright and competent people are not attracted to the civil service and do not want to stay on in the service? Significantly, the late Mr Edwards Deming, the father of "total quality management", once said bluntly, "pay is not a motivator." People are much more influenced by the opinions of their colleagues and the intrinsic interest of their work, rather than by crass material rewards. In fact, in my conversations with some people in the civil service, I learnt to my pleasant

Column: 853

surprise that there are some cases of people coming into the public sector from the private sector and who have taken a pay cut in doing so. Therefore, pegged salaries will not in themselves ensure that the right talent is attracted to the top posts and retained there. Attracting a person who possesses the right qualities will be more challenging and requires more than the promise of monetary rewards.

    Also, with the establishment of the Personnel Boards for the civil service, we should allow them to function, after which we could zoom in more effectively into the causes of disaffection within the civil service. We tend to make too many changes simultaneously, without giving ourselves an opportunity to assess a particular major change - in this case, the creation of the Personnel Boards.

    It seems to me, Mr Speaker, that many bright Administrative Officers plan their career path and follow it through at their own pace. This path consists of a stint in the public sector to gain experience and enhance their value, and then they get into a challenging and rewarding private sector job, and they end up as their own bosses. Those who have planned this trajectory will not be induced to stay longer in the civil service, even if we offer them much more than what they are getting. That is why it is important for us to look at what motivates bright young people. If they want to end up as their own bosses, then they are not going to wait around on the small chance of becoming a Permanent Secretary. After all, only one of them can become a Permanent Secretary. And so the other bright ones move out of the civil service while the going is good, ie, while the private sector is in need of them and they are in their 30s.

    This is again another area that the Personnel Boards may be able to throw light on. In fact, what the Prime Minister said confirms my thesis, as the 12 Administrative Officers left the civil service, soon after substantial pay increases were announced on 1st

Column: 854

January 1994. They were not seduced by the higher pay but followed their own planned career path.

    Now, Mr Speaker, I would like to address the issue of how we should pay our Ministers and top civil servants. The recent pay increases announced for January 1994 have brought the salaries of Ministers and top civil servants up to a handsome level. I would like to suggest that we continue to use this as our base line standard, and then adjust this each year according to the NWC recommended salary increase. The performance bonus of 0-6 months for Ministers gives the Prime Minister enough leeway to reward those with bigger responsibilities or with bigger Ministries. For our civil servants too, I suggest that we keep to the present salaries with NWC increments and let our Personnel Boards become responsive to the needs of civil servants and then reassess the situation in a few years' time with the experience and knowledge gained from the operation of the Personnel Boards.

    Finally, I would like to reiterate that I fully endorse the fairly high pay that our Ministers are getting now. But I would like to appeal to the Prime Minister not to raise the salaries any further for the short-term objective of attracting able people to become Ministers, and even the efficacy of this is in question and I have talked about this earlier, at the risk of long-term effects such as devaluing the worthiness of being a Minister and inviting public cynicism towards our political leaders and their commitment to office.

    In concluding, I would like to say that we are not being penny wise and pound foolish by not endorsing the pay rise. Another few million dollars makes little difference to us as a nation or on a personal level. But before we endorse the motion, we have to be satisfied as to the answers to these questions. Why are we unable to attract top talent into politics and public life? Are we categorically sure that the main obstacle is a perceived lack of financial rewards? If we increase the remuneration from the

Column: 855

present base which is already high, will we achieve our desired objective? Finally, what will be the political cost to the nation of this exercise?

have gone through a lot in life. They are very matured citizens. They command high salaries because they bring goodwill and talent to the company. The goodwill factor is important. arbitrary value. I think I am not wrong to propose an arbitrary value. What status do you want the Ministerial office to have? What

Column: 864

Column: 866

cannot be a valid benchmark. The children of the business owner are not a valid benchmark on what you pay the best in the public sector. Their earning capacity is inherited and not earned. People at this income level - and we are talking about 24 individuals - will not dare to have

Column: 867

undeclared perks with substantial money value.

Of course,

Column: 868

just as in the private sector, a degree of flexibility can be maintained to promote some beyond their age group bracket. Column: 869

variations on the adjustments. I would suggest that it is best to leave the actual adjustments to a body independent of the Government.

    Sir, with these comments, I end by supporting the principles set out in the White Paper.

sacrifice. To me, one of the greatest sacrifices a person can make is perhaps giving up totally one's personal freedom and privacy. servants. Ministers visit housing estates. They look at the old housing estates and they know that younger people are moving out from the older housing estates to newer ones at Bishan, Tampines, Pasir Ris. So they could see that the older housing estates were being hollowed out as these young people move and the old ones remain. So if we do not do something to the older housing estates, before long you are going to get very, very old people living in very old housing estates, and slums may emerge in the older housing estates.

    Mr Dhanabalan first directed this upgrading exercise. He went to Europe together with Mr Lim Hng Kiang who at that time was in the HDB. This is an example of a programme where Ministers make a difference to people's lives.

    The second example - Singapore Telecom IPO. The decision to corporatise and then float Singapore Telecom was initiated by the Ministers. We also decided to distribute Singapore Telecom shares widely amongst citizens to make Singapore a share-owning society. That is a political decision. That is not a civil service decision, to make Singapore a share-owning society. We wanted to do this on a scale never achieved anywhere else in the world. The civil servants got down to work. They appointed lead managers to work out at what price to sell Singapore Telecom shares and what discount to give to Singaporeans. They almost finalised the structure with the lead managers. Then one day, DPM came to see me. He said that Dr Yeo Ning Hong had told him that the ST price which would be quoted on the market at IPO was too low, and we would be giving so much money away. DPM felt the same way. Also, he felt that there were other issues to be resolved - policy issues, not technical issues, which

could not be done by the civil servants. For example, how much discount for shareholders and the quantum of loyalty bonus to prevent stagging.

    I asked him what was the solution. He suggested we form a Ministerial committee to deal with policies. I agreed. DPM chaired the committee. Then we had the Minister for Finance, Dr Richard Hu; Minister for Communications, Mr Mah Bow Tan; and Dr Yeo Ning Hong, the previous Minister for Communications and Information on the committee. The committee was assisted by the working level committee chaired by Mr Lim Siong Guan who was then Chairman of the CPF and also Permanent Secretary (Defence). The lead managers earned over $33 million from the Singapore Telecom listing, nearly $9 million in professional fees and nearly $25 million in commissions. And I would say that the lead managers fully deserved their earnings.

    I think the Ministerial committee should be given $12.5 million commission on the extra $2 billion which they collected for the Government. That is the price which they would have got if they were outside doing a job for Singapore Telecom. But they got nothing, not the civil servants, not the Ministers, not a cent. It is part of their normal job.

    The $33 million earned by the lead managers is sufficient to pay all the political office holders for two years. In one exercise, they earned that much. That is enough to pay all of us for two years. The $2 billion collected for the Government is sufficient to pay all of us at the revised salaries for 100 years.

    The third example where Ministers make a difference to the work of the civil service is the GST. When the GST was

Column: 899

introduced earlier this year, I regard it as the greatest non-event. And this is as a result of careful preparations before-hand to design the tax, to prepare the legislation, to work out a comprehensive offset package and to carry out extensive public education. The MOF, Inland Revenue Authority, MITA, MTI and MAS were all involved.

    The first draft of the GST White Paper in May 1992 was put up by the civil servants. But the draft dealt with the technicalities of the GST, and these were not answers which the public wanted to hear or see in the White Paper. They want to know what is the rate of the GST, what pain it will cause them, how they would be protected from the GST. Again, we got the Ministers involved. The Ministers who worked on the GST along with the civil servants were Deputy Prime Minister, Minister for Finance, Dr Richard Hu, the Minister for Trade and Industry, at that time Mr Dhanabalan, and later Minister of State for Finance, RAdm Teo Chee Hean.

    The draft was circulated many times to the Ministers for inputs. By the time the White Paper was published, it had been redrafted more than 30 times, and it was not just technical redrafting. The whole approach had been totally changed. Other countries have sacrificed their Finance Ministers when they introduced GST. I did not have to sacrifice Dr Richard Hu.

    Let me give you the last example which gives a very different facet of the work of civil servants and the Ministers, and in a way the strength required of civil servants and Ministers when they have to manage a crisis. This is the SQ 117 hijacking. SQ 117 was hijacked on 26th March 1991. The Executive Group (EG) comprising key Permanent Secretaries convened at Changi Airport to deal with the crisis. The EG comprised three key Permanent Secretaries - the PS (Home Affairs) as Chairman, PS (Defence) and PS (Foreign Affairs). The acting Chairman was Mr Lim Siong Guan because the Chairman, BG Tan Chin Tiong, was away overseas. The other key player was Mr Peter Chan, then PS (Foreign Affairs).

    The EG was formed a few years earlier when I was in the Defence Ministry. I suggested that we should have such a group to deal with contingencies. I knew the capabilities of the EG. I knew who were in the Executive Group and I knew the resources that they could muster to deal with emergencies, and crisis of this nature. The EG reported to the Minister for Home Affairs, at that time, Prof. Jayakumar. When the hijack took place, both Jayakumar and Yeo Ning Hong rushed to the airport. They were there together with the civil servants for the entire episode. Jayakumar kept me briefed on developments. The Ministers had to approve every key decision which had to be taken at each stage of the crisis. Uppermost in their minds was the safety of the passengers.

    At 6.43 am, Lim Siong Guan and the Chief of Defence Force, General Ng Jui Ping, reported to Jayakumar and Yeo Ning Hong that the situation was becoming critical. The hijackers were getting violent. They had doused the cockpit and the various instruments with alcohol. They threatened to kill people in five minutes if their demands were not met, and the threat was taken seriously because earlier on they had pushed out of the cabin two members of the aircraft crew.

    Lim Siong Guan asked for immediate approval to storm the plane. The two Ministers had to decide there and then. There was no time to ring me up for the final decision. Jayakumar asked General Ng: "Are your men ready?" "Yes, Sir," replied General Ng. Then the Minister said, "Proceed." By 7.00 am it was all over. A few minutes after that, Jayakumar rang me up. He said, "PM, it is all over. All the hijackers had been killed. No passenger was injured."

    Jayakumar and Yeo Ning Hong took the right decision, and the civil servants also came to the right assessment and gave the right recommendation to them. But they were also lucky. Supposing they were unlucky and the passengers were injured or killed. They would have been accountable, not the civil servants. Not Lim Siong Guan, Peter Chan, Ng Jui Ping or the Special Forces that were

there. The Ministers must take responsibility if things had gone wrong. I, as Prime Minister, would also have to take responsibility. I was Prime Minister at that time only for about four months.

    Jayakumar, Yeo Ning Hong, Lee Hsien Loong, Lim Siong Guan, these are the kind of people we want for Cabinet and for the Administrative Service. Lim Siong Guan was made Staff Grade I officer this year. Do not tell me that he is not worth over half a million dollars a year? Philip Yeo, not involved in all this, but also another Staff Grade I officer, is Chairman of EDB and Chairman of Sembawang. If Philip Yeo were not committed to the public service, he could easily go into the private sector and command a salary of over $1 million. No problem. There will be many people bidding for his services.

    So we come back to the basic question: what kind of Government do you want? That is, what kind of people do we target at to recruit for Government? Having targeted them, how do we pay them? Those who look at the salaries and say, "Wah, so high" are looking at the wrong end of the telescope. We look at actual people, what they can do and earn. They are able people we want. Of course, we look at other attributes - character, leadership qualities, compassion, dedication, feel for people. We look at actual people and we try to design terms of pay to match the kind of talent we want for Cabinet and the civil service.

    If I may illustrate this with the example of the Judiciary and the lawyers. If I want to appoint a Judge, from which pool would I search among the lawyers for a Judge? If I want to appoint a Law Minister sometime in the future and I want to look for a young

    Whilst we are talking about the formula, I have also been thinking for some time now how to accord tangible recognition to those other Singaporeans who laid the foundation for Singapore's progress and prosperity. They are the ones who planted the trees. The fruits which we enjoy today are because of the trees which they planted, the careful nurturing which they gave. They are not enjoying the fruits which we are all enjoying today. Certainly, not to the same extent which the younger generation is enjoying today.

    Singaporeans are caught up in a wave of the future, this wave of prosperity. But I think it is good that we sit back and, from time to time, reflect on who made all this possible. To more than just reflect, to recognise their contributions in some tangible ways.

    There are three groups of older Singaporeans whose past contributions I would like to recognise, and I would recommend that the House recognise their past contributions in tangible ways. First, the special group of MPs and Ministers whose stout-heartedness and great personal sacrifice made a difference to Singapore's history. They stood for elections between 1959 and before 1968 and retired by 1984, after which date we increased salaries significantly, ie, elections between 1959 and before 1968, those difficult crucial years, and retired before 1984 when we increased salaries. They fought the communists and the communalists, stayed on course despite personal risks to their lives and limbs. Without the courage and loyalty of the Assemblymen and MPs from 1959 to 1965, the Legislative Assembly would have gone to the Barisan Sosialis and Singapore's history would have taken a disastrous turn. Or Singapore would

Salary revisions were only made after the British military forces had been withdrawn without causing massive unemployment.

    I am now studying how to give tangible recognition to their past contributions. Only the MPs and the Ministers of this period who have made a difference to the fate of Singapore merit this special recognition. In other words, not all MPs or Ministers will get this tangible recognition. I shall consult the Senior Minister on the eligibility list.

    Next, we should not forget the second group, the public sector pensioners who retired before March 1972 when salaries were revised and pensionable public officers brought under the CPF Act. While their contributions to Singapore were not equal to that of the PAP MPs and Ministers, nevertheless, they worked for the Government during those turbulent times to tackle difficult problems. I have asked a working group to settle a fair and workable formula for this group of public sector pensioners. This will not apply to those civil servants who retired after 1972 when salaries have been adjusted.

    Third is a group of older Singaporeans who have retired before Medisave was introduced in 1984. They too, as ordinary Singaporeans, have worked hard, supported the Government but have no Medisave today. I shall ask the Minister for Finance to consider topping up their Medisave. I hope to finalise the details within six months.

In the final analysis, the debate is not about Ministers' pay, or benchmarking.
